There seems to be a bit of a conceptual conflict with #3247... In AIRFLOW-2348 the submitter says:

> I would expect the the operator behavior is similar to gsutil and would return the following result:

However, this is contrary to the docstring, which states

>  If a wildcard is supplied in the source_object argument, this is the prefix that will be prepended to the final destination objects' paths.

There is no mention of replacing the original path, and specifically I have a use case where I need to copy the whole source directory structure to the new location under the destination path.

Also #3247 has no tests, and based on my initial tests it seems not to work as supposed. I see the point behind AIRFLOW-2348 (if the structure needs to remain the same it can easily be prepended to `destination_object`), so I will update this PR to include better description in the docstring, as well as the tests.

@Fokko actually there are no differences: it's the same official docker python SDK package, but it has been renamed after v2.0. 
The official documentation (https://docker-py.readthedocs.io/en/stable/) now dictates the install to be `pip install docker` instead of `pip install docker-py`

Ack, thanks. It looks like 3.3.0 is the current version. Maybe bump it to 3+ right away?

https://pypi.org/project/docker/

That's what's already happening. 
`pip` will by default use the most recent stable version (which is 3.3.0 at the moment). I have only placed the requirements that it is `>=2.0` but not fixed it at that. 

You can see it in the travis log:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/112610/39518152-ee6729e0-4df9-11e8-93b0-613a84b20c78.png)

Looks like Travis build failed at unrelated test case `test_authorized` - can someone retry it? 

I like this change - we were looking at this option for some time already.
@ebartkus Could you rebase onto master please? The flaky test has been fixed earlier.
@Fokko done

LOL...  __this__ is an undefined name...

flake8 testing of https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow on Python 3.6.3

$ __flake8 . --count --select=E901,E999,F821,F822,F823 --show-source --statistics__
```
./airflow/contrib/sensors/qubole_sensor.py:62:9: F821 undefined name 'this'
        this.log.info('Poking: %s', self.data)
        ^
./airflow/contrib/sensors/qubole_sensor.py:68:13: F821 undefined name 'logging'
            logging.exception(e)
            ^
./airflow/contrib/sensors/qubole_sensor.py:71:9: F821 undefined name 'this'
        this.log.info('Status of this Poke: %s', status)
        ^
```
__this__ also conflicts with the standard library module:
$ __python__
    >>> import this
Codecov seems to use this, nvm

@Fokko I was speaking with @schnie from Astronomer.io last night and he mentioned a solution to the logging issue that they've implemented in their branch of the kubernetes executor. Basically because task-level logs don't get logged to the default log folder, k8s doesn't pick up those logs when you query the pod. To solve this, they have a side-car that reads the task log files to stdout. This should be somewhat straightforward to implement, though I'd rather @schnie PR it so he can get the credit :).

@andscoop 

Sorry for my previous comment. I took a second look in your code design and noticed the fact that all your mongo functions first need to call get_collection() which again calls get_conn(), creates a mongoClient, and then do some operations. 

Creating new MongoClient object multiple times could be very expensive if you need to use MongoHook to do some operations in few steps as each MongoClient is handling a separate connection pool. (Check here: http://api.mongodb.com/python/current/faq.html#how-does-connection-pooling-work-in-pymongo) 

It would be better if you can reuse one MongoClient object in your methods (check if the Client object is already created) instead of calling get_conn() every time and then add a function to explicitly close the Client. 

Again, please correct me if I am wrong about your design.

Thanks!
